captions.text:
Look at the earth - isn't it beautiful? Blue
oceans, white polar ice-caps, and verdant

green land. Some brown as well, where there
aren't as many plants. But why are those parts

of our earth barren, and others green? I mean,
deserts cover much of Africa and Australia,
but not Europe!

Europeans, it turns out, discovered the answer,
but in the most unlikely of places - the oceans!

When sailing from Europe, trade winds pushed
ships enthusiastically southwest to the equator,

where suddenly, the winds would die. These
were the doldrums. And for sailors, they were
a pain.

They were also annoying to scientists like
Galileo, Kepler, and Halley, who all had theories

about why the wind blew to the southwest:
Did the wind somehow follow the sun from morning

til night? Or maybe it had trouble keeping
up with the ground spinning beneath it?

In 1735, a London lawyer and amateur meteorologist
named George Hadley came up with an even brighter

idea that ultimately helped explain not just
ocean winds, but also why our planet has rainforests

in a belt near the equator and deserts just
north and south of that.

Hadley figured that, since the sun warms the
Earth most at the equator, air to the north

and south must be cooler--and therefore more
dense. Just as cold air rushes in through

an open door in winter, cool air north and
south of the equator must flow toward the

warm air in the middle, bringing sailors with
it.

There, in the doldrums, the air didn't actually
stop moving, it just headed upwards, heat

rising to make way for the denser air flowing
in from both sides. And here's where the earth's
greens and browns come in:

As warm, humid air at the equator rises, it
cools, and--since cool air can't hold as much

moisture as warm air--it rains. A lot. Enough
to make rain-forests.

After reaching an altitude of about 17 kilometers,
the rising (and drying) air hits the stratosphere,

which acts kind of like a ceiling, causing
the warm air to spread out and separate -- some

goes north, some south. As the air leaves
the equator, it rains away more moisture,

becoming denser and slightly cooler, until
finally dry, it sinks, creating the arid bands
where many of the world's famous deserts lie.

This giant atmospheric conveyor belt, officially
called a Hadley cell, brings us both tropical

rainforests and deserts. So the locations
of the greens and browns of the earth come
courtesy of a lot of hot air.

comments.text:
This video is just about the general banding of rainforests and deserts, 
but it is not a rule. There are other, more-local factors that also come 
into play such as mountain ranges and over-farming/grazing. Mountain ranges 
work in much the same way as convection currents in that wet air is forced 
upward on one side causing it to condense and precipitate, and then falls 
on the other side when it is dry. Over-farming/grazing degrades the soil 
and removes plant life which reduces the soil's ability to hold water or 
support large plants, creating a dry, barren expanse.

I know I'm late, but desert form by rain shadow, or the way they explain in 
the video. Deserts near the equartors form from (like how its explain the 
video) convection. Warm air rises, and cool air sinks. Deserts farther away 
from the equator, like Arizona in the U.S., form because of rain shadow. 
See, Arizona, is surrounded by mountains, the Rocky Mountains to be exact. 
Rain shadow is when one side of mountainous terrain get rain, while the 
other side gets dry conditions, casting a shadow of dryness on the other 
side. When moist air goes up one side of the mountain, it rises with the 
mountain. This cools the moist air, because higher altitude have colder 
air. This cause the moist air to form clouds. As the air cools more the 
cloud drops its moisture through rain, or snow, as cold air can not hold as 
much moisture as warm air. By the the the air reaches the other side of the 
mountain, and begins to warm up, most of it's moisture is depleted, so it 
become dry air. This form arid conditions.

comments.text:
The Earth isn't symmetric. Deserts and rainforests can be affected by 
various other factors like altitude, geographical features (mountains, 
coast-lines, slopes), and human & animal interactions. Landmasses 
(continents) can also have an effect on wind & precipitation which are 
massive factors.
The Sahel/Sahara regions are becoming more arid because of overgrazing 
(loss of vegetation; thus no soil anchorage ~ similar to the Dust bowls in 
the US) and removal of manure (used as fuel instead of adding organic 
matter for plant growth). River patterns and irrigation can add more 
variation (e.g The Nile).

It's not as clear looking at a flat map but the Hadley Cell is still one of 
the largest factors causing it. Things are rarely that straight forward; 
having exceptions to nearly everything.

comments.text:
There is a mistake in this video. You say that cold air during winter 
rushes through an open door. This is untrue, the reason the house gets 
colder is because warm air inside the house rushes out. This is because 
warm air has molecules with more kinetic energy, hitting the sides of the 
room with greater force and therefore causing the air pressure inside of 
the room to be higher than the air pressure of the cold air outside. This 
difference in air pressure causes the warm air to rush out, not the cold 
air to rush in. ﻿
